title: How to Schedule an Email Message in Microsoft Outlook

steps.title: Compose a message in Microsoft Outlook.
steps.content: Compose a message in Microsoft Outlook. This method delays the delivery of a single email message on both Windows and macOS. Click New Email and fill out the details of your email message, including recipients, subject, and body. Remember to include any attachments you'd like to send. Did you know you can also unsend emails in Outlook ? This is a great feature to try alongside delaying emails.

steps.title: Click the Message menu.
steps.content: Click the Message menu. It's at the top of the New Message window.

steps.title: Make sure you're looking at the "Classic View" of the ribbon.
steps.content: Make sure you're looking at the "Classic View" of the ribbon. You should now see several icons in groups at the top of the new message window. The groups are called Undo, Clipboard, Basic Text, Names, Include, Tags, and a few others. If you only see some simple icons and not these menu groups, click the down arrow on the far-right side of the toolbar and select Classic Ribbon .

steps.title: Click the More Options icon in the "Tags" section of the ribbon.
steps.content: Click the More Options icon in the "Tags" section of the ribbon. This is the arrow pointing downward and to the right in the "Tags" panel of the ribbon. A Properties window will expand. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Check the "Do not deliver before" box.
steps.content: Check the "Do not deliver before" box. This is in the "Delivery options" section of the window. You'll find the option to delay an email here. [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select the date and time you want the email to send.
steps.content: Select the date and time you want the email to send. You can change the date and time in the drop-down boxes next to the "Do not deliver before." [3] X Research source

steps.title: Click Close.
steps.content: Click Close . Your delivery preferences for this email will be saved.

steps.title: Click Send in the email composition window.
steps.content: Click Send in the email composition window. This will place the email in your "Outbox" folder. Your message is now delayed and won't be sent until the scheduled date and time. [4] X Research source If you decide you don't want to send a delayed email, you can follow these steps to send the message immediately: Go to the "Outbox" folder in the left panel and open the message. Click the More Options icon (the arrow) in the "Tags" section. Uncheck the "Do not deliver before" check box. Click Close to close the "Properties" window. Click Send in the email composition window to send the message.

steps.title: Click the File menu in Microsoft Outlook.
steps.content: Click the File menu in Microsoft Outlook. If you want to delay all email messages for a specific period of time, use this method. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Click Manage Rules & Alerts.
steps.content: Click Manage Rules & Alerts . This is the icon with a gear and a bell on the right panel. [6] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source This opens the Rules and Alerts panel. If you have any existing rules to filter inbound or outbound email messages, they'll appear here.

steps.title: Click the New Rule… button.
steps.content: Click the New Rule… button. It's at the top of the "Email Rules" tab. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Select "Apply rule on messages I send" and click Next.
steps.content: Select "Apply rule on messages I send" and click Next . This option is under the "Start from a blank rule" section.

steps.title: Select the conditions and click Next.
steps.content: Select the conditions and click Next . For example, selecting "sent to people or public group" will allow you to delay emails sent to individuals and groups. You can also select no conditions to have the delay rule apply to all sent emails.

steps.title: Click defer delivery by a number of minutes.
steps.content: Click defer delivery by a number of minutes . [8] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click a number of under Step 2.
steps.content: Click a number of under Step 2. This is in the second box labeled "Step 2: Edit the rule description (click an underlined value)." A small window will appear. [9] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Type in how long you want emails to be delayed by, and then click OK.
steps.content: Type in how long you want emails to be delayed by, and then click OK . You can enter anywhere from 1 to 120 minutes. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Click Next.
steps.content: Click Next .

steps.title: Select exceptions and then click Next.
steps.content: Select exceptions and then click Next . Adding exceptions is optional.

steps.title: Type in a name for the rule.
steps.content: Type in a name for the rule. This could be something like "sent email delay rule."

steps.title: Check the "Turn on this rule" check box and then click Finish.
steps.content: Check the "Turn on this rule" check box and then click Finish . You're done! All emails sent will be placed in the "Outbox" folder and delayed until the specified time goes by. [11] X Research source Now that you've automated delayed emails, you can also check out how to add a signature .

steps.title: Click the File tab in Microsoft Outlook.
steps.content: Click the File tab in Microsoft Outlook. This will open a new page with various options. This method allows you to create an Outlook rule that all sent emails are delayed by up to 2 hours. Note that this method won't work if you don't control your Outlook server (e.g., you're using a work account).

steps.title: Click Options at the bottom-left corner.
steps.content: Click Options at the bottom-left corner.

steps.title: Click Advanced in the left panel.
steps.content: Click Advanced in the left panel.

steps.title: Uncheck the "Send immediately when connected" box.
steps.content: Uncheck the "Send immediately when connected" box. This is under the "Send and receive" section.

steps.title: Click the Send/Receive… button.
steps.content: Click the Send/Receive… button. It's under the "Send and receive" section. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Uncheck the 2 "automatic send/receive" boxes.
steps.content: Uncheck the 2 "automatic send/receive" boxes. Remove the checkmarks from the boxes next to "Schedule an automatic send/receive every 30 minutes" and "Perform an automatic send/receive when exiting."

steps.title: Click Close and then OK.
steps.content: Click Close and then OK . This will confirm the sending and receiving settings. Now, Outlook will only send and receive emails when you manually request it to. Now that your email will not be sent as soon as you click the Send button, you'll need to send your emails manually. No messages will be sent or received until you complete these steps: Go to the Send/Receive tab. Click the Send/Receive All Folders button.
